Article.ArticleTitle: Realizing 1,1-Dehydration of Secondary Alcohols to Carbenes: Pyrrolidin-2-ols as a Source of Cyclic (Alkyl)(Amino)Carbenes.

AbstractText: Herein we report secondary pyrrolidin-2-ols as a source of cyclic (alkyl)(amino)carbenes (CAAC) for the synthesis of CAAC-Cu<sup>I</sup> -complexes and cyclic thiones when reacted with Cu<sup>I</sup> -salts and elemental sulfur, respectively, under reductive elimination of water from the carbon(IV)-center. This result demonstrates a convenient and facile access to CAAC-based Cu<sup>I</sup> -salts, which are well known catalysts for different organic transformations. It further establishes secondary alcohols to be a viable source of carbenes-realizing after 185 years Dumas' dream who tried to prepare the parent carbene (CH<sub>2</sub> ) by 1,1-dehydration of methanol. Addressed is also the reactivity of water towards CAACs, which proceeds through an oxidative addition of the O-H bond to the carbon(II)-center. This emphasizes the ability of carbon-compounds to mimic the reactivity of transition-metal complexes: reversible oxidative addition and reductive elimination of the O-H bond to/from the C(II)/C(IV)-centre.

The preparation of 1Me-D2 is challenging, therefore to address the possible reaction mechanisms we have considered the heating of 4Me-D2 at 235 °C. This leads to the formation of 8Me-H/D, with the imine hydrogen as a mixture of H and D isotopes (N=C−H/D), 9Me , and 10Me . This observation is in contrast to that of non-deuterated analogue 4Me where the heating exclusively leads to dehydrated product 8Me . This strikingly distinct behaviour (higher thermal stability (not being dehydrated at 200 °C) and formation of different products upon heating), of 4Me-D2 with respect to the corresponding non-deuterated compound 4Me is most likely due to the isotope effect. However, the results also suggest that the dehydration of hydrated CAAC 1Me and 4Me are following more than only one pathway. This is, hence, along the lines of recently reported three concomitant C−C dissociation pathways of carbene-based molecules, which also reflect the isotope effects on the mode of bond-activation.[43]
